datafield.subfield: Oral history interviews conducted by recording industry executive Joe Smith with more than two hundred recording artists and executives from 1986 through 1988. Printed transcripts accompany most of the recorded interviews.
Off the record: an oral history of popular music.
Motion Picture, Broadcasting, and Recorded Sound Division

titlestmt.author: Author: Carla Arton, with contributions from Bryan Cornell

publicationstmt.publisher: Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division, Library of Congress

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Marsha Maguire, 2012
profiledesc.descrules: Finding aid prepared using DACS (Describing Archives: A Content Standard)

change.item: Links to Joe Smith Collection web page and digital audio added to finding aid. M. Maguire

did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Joe Smith collection 1986-1988

repository.label: Location
repository.corpname: Recorded Sound Reference Center, Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division Library of Congress

did.abstract: Oral history interviews conducted by recording industry executive Joe Smith with more than two hundred recording artists and executives from 1986 through 1988. Printed transcripts accompany most of the recorded interviews.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

controlaccess.head: Titles
controlaccess.title: Off the record: an oral history of popular music.

controlaccess.head: Occupations
controlaccess.occupation: Sound recording executives and producers--United States.

acqinfo.head: Collection Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The audiocassettes and transcripts were donated to the Library of Congress by Joe Smith in April 2010.
263 recordable compact discs, which often duplicated the content of the audiocassettes, were on loan from Joe Smith for copying. Following preservation duplication, they were returned to the donor.

accruals.head: Additions
accruals.p: No further additions to the collection are expected.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Carla Arton in 2011.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Restrictions may exist on copying, quoting, or publishing materials included in the collection. For additional information, contact a reference librarian in the Recorded Sound Reference Center, Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division, Library of Congress, Washington, DC, 20540-4690; (202) 707-7833.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Joe Smith Collection is open for research. Advance notice is required; contact a reference librarian in the Recorded Sound Reference Center, Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division, Library of Congress, Washington, DC, 20540-4690; (202) 707-7833.

altformavail.head: Digital Format
altformavail.p: A digital version of the audiocassettes is available for listening in the Recorded Sound Reference Center, Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division, Library of Congress, Washington, DC, 20540-4690; (202) 707-7833.
Interview excerpts and some complete interviews are also available at the Recorded Sound Reference Center's online presentation about the collection: http://www.loc.gov/rr/record/joesmith/index.html

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [Container number, eg., RPA 00461], or [Audio tape number, eg., RYN 0159], Joe Smith Collection, Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division, Library of Congress.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Born in Chelsea, Massachusetts, and educated at Yale University, Joe Smith worked as a sportscaster and disc jockey in Virginia and Pennsylvania before becoming a top-rated and pioneering rock ‘n’ roll disc jockey at WMEX and WBZ in Boston. In 1961 he moved to California and was hired as a national promotion manager for Warner Bros. Records. Over the next three decades, until his retirement in 1993, he rose to legendary status as president of three major labels: Warner Bros./Reprise, Electra/Asylum/Nonesuch and Capitol/EMI. He signed and guided the careers of such artists as Peter, Paul, and Mary; Bill Cosby; Rod Stewart; James Taylor; the Grateful Dead; Linda Ronstadt; the Eagles; Bonnie Raitt; Van Morrison; the Doobie Brothers; and Black Sabbath.

During his career Joe Smith was heavily involved in various industry associations, acting as the first full-time president of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences (NARAS), vice president of the Country Music Association, president of the Record Industry for Community Relations, and a board member of the Recording Industry Association (RIAA) and Black Music Association. Smith was a leading music industry spokesman in Washington and overseas, advocating for copyright protection and testifying against piracy before several congressional committees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: During 1986-1988, Joe Smith, then president of Capitol Records/EMI, managed to get more than two hundred celebrated singers, musicians, and industry icons to talk about their lives, music, experiences, and contemporaries. Excerpts from the 238 hours of interviews were then compiled and presented in his groundbreaking book, Off the Record, published by Warner Books in 1988.

The list of 243 noted artists and executives who were interviewed by Smith includes Artie Shaw, Woody Herman, Ella Fitzgerald, Ray Charles, Barbra Streisand, Little Richard, Bob Dylan, Paul McCartney, George Harrison, Elton John, Paul Simon, David Bowie, Billy Joel, Sting, Tony Bennett, Joan Baez, James Taylor, Dick Clark, Tina Turner, Tom Jones, B.B. King, Quincy Jones, David Geffen, Mickey Hart, Harry Belafonte, and many others. All types of popular music are represented — from rock ‘n’ roll, jazz, rhythm & blues, and pop to big-band, heavy metal, folk, and country-western.

The Joe Smith Collection (also known as the Off the Record Collection) consists of 263 audiocassettes and 225 accompanying paper transcripts. The donated audiocassettes and transcripts are permanently held at the Library of Congress (Joe Smith also temporarily loaned CD-R copies of the interviews for digital transfer). Most of these candid and unabridged interviews were conducted by Joe Smith informally in a home, hotel, restaurant, or over the phone, while a handful were recorded for radio programs such as Westwood One and View from the Top.
The accompanying transcripts are housed in boxes RPA 00461 to RPA 00469. For availability and location of individual transcripts, see the inventory section of this finding aid.

arrangement.head: Collection Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged alphabetically by name of interviewee or band.

note.p: Unless otherwise noted, the interviews were conducted by Joe Smith.

Original audiocassettes were not available for several of the interviews. For those interviews, digital preservation and listening copies were made from CD-Rs on loan from Joe Smith and subsequently returned to him.

bibliography.head: Sources Consulted
bibliography.bibref: Off the Record: an Oral History of Popular Music, stories told to Joe Smith; edited by Mitchell Fink. New York: Warner Books, 1988.

bibref.title: "Joe Smith Donates Recorded Interviews with Music’s Who’s Who to the Library of Congress.”
bibref.imprint: Library of Congress news release, June 18, 2012; accessed October 9, 2012. http://www.loc.gov/today/pr/2012/12-117.html

relatedmaterial.p: The business papers of Joe Smith, including research materials for his book, Off the Record, are available at the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame Library and Archives: http://catalog.rockhall.com/catalog/ARC-0158#
